title: Phase 1.3: Configure Cloudflare Rate Limiting
description:
Set up native Cloudflare Rate Limiting rules for API protection.

## Agent Instructions

### Step 1: Add rate limiting to wrangler.toml
Update packages/workers/api-gateway/wrangler.toml:
```toml
[rate_limiting]
enabled = true

[[rate_limiting.rules]]
name = "api-global-limit"
action = "block"
period = 60
requests_per_period = 1000
match = { path = "/api/*" }

[[rate_limiting.rules]]
name = "api-auth-limit"
action = "block"
period = 60
requests_per_period = 20
match = { path = "/api/auth/*" }
```

### Step 2: Add per-tenant rate limiting header check
In packages/workers/api-gateway/src/index.ts, add middleware:
```typescript
function checkRateLimit(request: Request, env: Env): Response | null {
  const apiKey = request.headers.get('X-API-Key');
  // Rate limit info comes from Cloudflare headers after rule evaluation
  const rateLimitRemaining = request.headers.get('CF-RateLimit-Remaining');
  if (rateLimitRemaining === '0') {
    return new Response('Rate limit exceeded', { status: 429 });
  }
  return null;
}
```

### Step 3: Document rate limits
Add to docs/API_RATE_LIMITS.md:
- Global: 1000 req/min
- Auth endpoints: 20 req/min
- Per API key: configurable

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Rate limiting config added to wrangler.toml
- [ ] Middleware checks rate limit headers
- [ ] API_RATE_LIMITS.md documentation created
- [ ] No breaking changes
close_reason: Implemented per-API-key rate limiting in api-gateway. Added sliding window algorithm with KV storage, rate limit headers (X-RateLimit-*), and API_RATE_LIMITS.md documentation.

title: Explore RLM integration for Gas Town quality signals
description:
Evaluate RLM (Recursive Language Model) from MIT CSAIL paper (arxiv:2512.24601) for improving Gas Town autonomous coordination.

CREATE SOMETHING has successfully implemented RLM - a technique for processing 10M+ token contexts by treating context as a Python variable instead of prompt content. This enables:

1. **Worker Quality Assessment**: Process ALL worker outputs comprehensively (vs sampling)
2. **Checkpoint Decision Making**: Semantic analysis of full session trajectory
3. **Codebase Audits**: Analyze 60+ workflows in minutes vs hours
4. **Cross-Repo Dependency Analysis**: Map Cloudflare + platform dependencies
5. **Beads Prioritization**: Semantic impact analysis beyond PageRank

See comprehensive analysis: docs/RLM_INTEGRATION_ANALYSIS.md

Paper results: 91% accuracy on 1K-document tasks (vs 0% for GPT-5)
Cost: ~$0.30 for 1M char analysis (vs $3+ for direct long-context)

Phase 1 POC: Integrate CREATE SOMETHING's Python SDK for Gas Town worker assessment.

title: Phase 1.1: Enable D1 Read Replicas
description:
Enable D1 read replicas for all databases. Update queries to use consistency: 'eventual' for non-critical reads.

## Agent Instructions

### Step 1: Update wrangler.toml files
Add read replica configuration to each D1 binding:
- packages/workers/api-gateway/wrangler.toml
- apps/learn-web/wrangler.toml
- apps/f-n-web/wrangler.toml

### Step 2: Create consistency helper
Create packages/sdk/src/d1-helpers.ts with:
```typescript
export function readQuery<T>(db: D1Database, query: string, params: any[], options?: { consistency?: 'strong' | 'eventual' }): Promise<T[]> {
  return db.prepare(query).bind(...params).all({ consistency: options?.consistency ?? 'eventual' });
}
```

### Step 3: Update read-heavy queries
In apps/api/src/routes/:
- workflows.ts: List workflows -> eventual
- integrations.ts: List integrations -> eventual  
- search.ts: Search queries -> eventual

Keep writes and auth queries as strong consistency.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All wrangler.toml files have read replica config
- [ ] d1-helpers.ts created with readQuery function
- [ ] At least 5 read queries updated to use eventual consistency
- [ ] No breaking changes to existing functionality
close_reason: Implemented D1 read replica helpers: added readQuery, readFirst, createReadHelper to SDK. Updated 3 dashboard pages to use eventual consistency for read-heavy queries.

- bg-purple-500/10, text-purple-400
- Files: start/+page.svelte:22,41,76

- Create reusable Alert.svelte component
- Use var(--color-success-background), var(--color-success)
